article.title: Necrophilia
article.text:
{{Distinguish2|[[Necrophila]], a genus of beetles}}
{{Infobox medical condition
| Name           = Necrophilia
| Image          =Pietro Pajetta - Der Hass - 1896.jpeg
| Caption        =''The Hatred'', painted by [[Pietro Pajetta]], 1896.
| Field          = [[Psychiatry]]
| DiseasesDB     =
| ICD10          = {{ICD10|F|65.8}} }}
'''Necrophilia''', also known as '''necrophilism''', '''necrolagnia''', '''necrocoitus''', '''necrochlesis''', and '''thanatophilia''',{{sfn|Aggrawal|2016|p=1}} is a [[sexual attraction]] or sexual act involving [[Cadaver|corpses]]. It is classified as a [[paraphilia]] by the ''[[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual]]'' (DSM) of the [[American Psychiatric Association]].<ref name="goodwin">{{cite book|title=Inappropriate Relationships: The Unconventional, the Disapproved, and the Forbidden|pages=174–176|author1=Robin Goodwin|author2=Duncan Cramer|publisher=Psychology Press|year=2002}}</ref>

Rosman and Resnick (1989) reviewed information from 34 cases of necrophilia describing the individuals' motivations for their behaviors: these individuals reported the desire to possess a non-resisting and non-rejecting partner (68%), reunions with a romantic partner (21%), sexual attraction to corpses (15%), comfort or overcoming feelings of isolation (15%), or seeking self-esteem by expressing power over a homicide victim (12%).<ref name="rosman">{{cite journal | last1 = Rosman | first1 = J. P. | last2 = Resnick | first2 = P. J. | date = 1 June 1989 | title = Sexual attraction to corpses: A psychiatric review of necrophilia | url = http://www.jaapl.org/content/17/2/153.full.pdf+html?sid=94a1e953-67b0-44c0-95a6-75ee304d916e | format=PDF/HTML| journal = Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law | volume = 17 | issue = 2| pages = 153–163 | pmid = 2667656 }}</ref>

==Origins of term==
The term 'necrophilia' is thought to have been coined by Belgian physician [[Joseph Guislain]] in his ''Leçons Orales sur les Phrénopathies'', in a lecture given around 1850, in reference to contemporary necrophile [[François Bertrand]]:<ref>Aggrawal p.4</ref> 
{{quote|It is within the category of the destructive madmen [''aliénés destructeurs''] that one needs to situate certain patients to whom I would like to give the name of necrophiliacs [''nécrophiles'']. The alienists have adopted, as a new form, the case of Sergeant Bertrand, the disinterrer of cadavers on whom all the newspapers have recently reported. However, don’t think that we are dealing here with a form of phrenopathy which appears for the first time. The ancients, in speaking about lycanthropy, have cited examples to which one can more or less relate the case which has just attracted the public attention so strongly.}}
The term was popularized about a decade later by psychiatrist [[Bénédict Morel]], who also discussed Bertrand.<ref name="goodwin" />

==History==
In the ancient world, sailors returning corpses to their home country were often accused of necrophilia.{{sfn|Aggrawal|2016|p=2}} Singular accounts of necrophilia in history are sporadic, though written records suggest the practice was present within [[Ancient Egypt]]. [[Herodotus]] writes in [[Histories (Herodotus)|''The Histories'']] that, to discourage intercourse with a corpse, ancient [[Egypt]]ians left deceased beautiful women to decay for "three or four days" before giving them to the [[embalmers]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Herodotus (c. 440 BC) |title=The Histories (Book 2) |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/2707 |quote=The wives of men of rank when they die are not given at once to be embalmed, nor such women as are very beautiful or of greater regard than others, but on the third or fourth day after their death (and not before) they are delivered to the embalmers. They do so about this matter in order that the embalmers may not abuse their women, for they say that one of them was taken once doing so to the corpse of a woman lately dead, and his fellow-craftsman gave information.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Brill | first1 = Abraham A. | year = 1941 | title = Necrophilia | journal = Journal of Criminal Psychopathology | volume = 2 | issue = 4| pages = 433–443 }}</ref><ref name="klaf">{{cite journal |author1=Klaf, Franklin S. |author2=Brown, William  |lastauthoramp=yes | year = 1958 | title = Necrophilia: Brief Review and Case Report | journal = Psychiatric Quarterly | volume = 32 | issue = 4 | pages = 645–652 | quote = Inhibited forms of necrophilia and necrophiliac fantasies may occur more commonly then is generally realized. | doi=10.1007/bf01563024}}</ref> Herodotus also alluded to suggestions that Greek tyrant [[Periander]] had defiled the corpse of his wife, employing a metaphor: "Periander baked his bread in a cold oven."<ref>{{cite book | author = Aggrawal, Anil | year = 2010 | title = Necrophilia: Forensic and Medico-legal Aspects | publisher = CRC Press | pages = 6–7}} The primary source is ''Histories'', Book V, 92.</ref> Acts of necrophilia are depicted on ceramics from the [[Moche (culture)|Moche]] culture, which reigned in northern [[Peru]] from the first to eighth century CE.<ref>{{cite book | author = Finbow, Steve | year = 2014 | title = Grave Desire: A Cultural History of Necrophilia | publisher = John Hunt Publishing | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=rGIpBQAAQBAJ&lpg=PT4&ots=74OrhG8hA4&pg=PT39}}</ref> A common theme in these artifacts is the masturbation of a male skeleton by a living woman.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Weismantel, M. | year = 2004 | title = Moche sex pots: Reproduction and temporality in ancient South America | journal = American Anthropologist | volume = 106 | issue = 3 | pages = 495–496 | url = http://www.latinamericanstudies.org/moche/moche-sex-pots.pdf | doi=10.1525/aa.2004.106.3.495}}</ref> [[Hittites|Hittite]] law from the 16th century BC through to the 13th century BC explicitly permitted sex with the dead.<ref>{{cite book | author = Boer, Roland | year = 2014 | title = Sex in Antiquity: Exploring Gender and Sexuality in the Ancient World | chapter = From Horse Kissing to Beastly Emissions: Paraphilias in the Ancient Near East | editor = Masterson, Mark | publisher = Routledge | page = 69 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=k1G2BQAAQBAJ&lpg=PA69&ots=DtUbHRO19Dlr&pg=PA69#v=onepage}}</ref>

In [[Renaissance Italy]], following the reputed moral collapse brought about by the [[Black Death]] and before the [[Roman Inquisition]] of the [[Counter-Reformation]], the literature was replete with sexual references; these include necrophilia, in the case of the epic poem ''[[Orlando Innamorato]]'' by [[Matteo Maria Boiardo]], first published in 1483.<ref name="DavidsonDean1994">{{cite journal|last1=Davidson|first1=Nicholas|last2=Dean|first2=Trevor|last3=Lowe|first3=K. J. P.|title=Theology, nature and the law: sexual sin and sexual crime in Italy from the fourteenth to the seventeenth century|year=1994|pages=74–98|doi=10.1017/CBO9780511523410.006}}</ref> In a notorious modern example, American [[serial killer]] [[Jeffrey Dahmer]] was a necrophiliac. Dahmer wanted to create a [[sex slave]] that would mindlessly consent to whatever he wanted. When his attempts failed, and his victim died, he would keep the corpse until it decomposed beyond recognition, continuously masturbating and performing sexual intercourse on the body.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.comicextra.com/my-friend-dahmer/chapter-Full/214|title=My Friend Dahmer #Full - Read My Friend Dahmer Issue #Full Page 214|website=www.comicextra.com|access-date=2017-12-20}}</ref> In order to be aroused, he had to murder his victims before performing sexual intercourse with them.
Dahmer stated that he only killed his victims because they wanted to leave after having sex, and would be angry with him for drugging them.<ref>{{cite web|title=Psychiatric Testimony of Jeffrey Dahmer|url=http://www.criminalprofiling.com/Psychiatric-Testimony-of-Jeffrey-Dahmer_s115.html|work=Court Transcripts|publisher=Criminal Profiling|date=8 June 2001|accessdate=29 November 2012}}</ref> British serial killer [[Dennis Nilsen]] is also considered to have been a necrophiliac.<ref>{{cite book | author = Masters, Brian | year = 1985 | title = Killing For Company | publisher = Arrow | isbn = 978-0099552611}}</ref>

==Classification==
In the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]], fifth edition ([[DSM-5]]), recurrent, intense sexual interest in corpses can be diagnosed under [[Other Specified Paraphilic Disorder]] (necrophilia) when it causes marked distress or impairment in important areas of functioning.<ref name="DSM-5">{{cite book | title = Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition | chapter = Other Specified Paraphilic Disorder, 302.89 (F65.89) | editor = American Psychiatric Association | year = 2013 | publisher = American Psychiatric Publishing | page = 705}}</ref> A ten-tier classification of necrophilia exists:<ref name="aggrawal_classification">{{cite journal |author=Aggrawal, Anil |title=A new classification of necrophilia |journal=Journal of Forensic and Legal Medicine |volume=16 |issue=6 |pages=316–20 |year=2009 |pmid=19573840 |doi=10.1016/j.jflm.2008.12.023 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1752928X08002564}} {{subscription required}}</ref>
# Role players: People who get aroused from [[Sexual roleplay|pretending]] their live partner is dead during sexual activity.
# Romantic necrophiliacs: Bereaved people who remain attached to their dead lover's body.
# Necrophilic fantasizers: People who fantasize about necrophilia, but never actually have sex with a corpse.
# Tactile necrophiliacs: People who are aroused by touching or stroking a corpse, without engaging in intercourse.
# [[Sexual fetishism|Fetishistic]] necrophiliacs: People who remove objects (e.g., panties or a tampon) or body parts (e.g., a finger or genitalia) from a corpse for sexual purposes, without engaging in intercourse.
# Necromutilomaniacs: People who derive pleasure from mutilating a corpse while masturbating, without engaging in intercourse.
# Opportunistic necrophiliacs: People who normally have no interest in necrophilia, but take the opportunity when it arises.
# Regular necrophiliacs: People who preferentially have intercourse with the dead.
# Homicidal necrophiliacs: Necrosadists,{{sfn|Purcell|2006|p=21}} people who commit [[lust murder|murder]] in order to have sex with the victim.
# Exclusive necrophiliacs: People who have an exclusive interest in sex with the dead, and cannot perform at all for living partner
Additionally, criminologist [[Lee Mellor]]'s typology of homicidal necrophiles consists of eight categories (A-H), and is based on the combination of two behavioral axes: destructive (offender [[Mutilation|mutilates]] the corpse for sexual reasons) - preservative (offender does not), and cold (offender used the corpse sexually two hours after death) - warm (offender used the corpse sexually earlier than two hours after death).<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Homicide: A Forensic Psychology Casebook|last=Mellor|first=Lee|publisher=CRC|year=2016|isbn=|location=Boca Raton , FL|pages=103-105}}</ref> This renders four categories (A-D) to which Mellor adds an additional four (E-H):
* Category A (cold/destructive), eg. [[Ted Bundy]], [[Jeffrey Dahmer]]
* Category B (cold/preservative), eg. [[Gary Ridgway]], [[Dennis Nilsen]]
* Category C (warm/destructive) eg. [[Andrei Chikatilo]], [[Joseph Vacher]]
* Category D (warm/preservative) eg. [[Robert Lee Yates|Robert Yates]], [[Earle Nelson]]
* Category E (dabblers) eg. [[Richard Ramirez]], [[Mark Dixie]]
* Category F ([[Fredric Wertham|catathymic]]) 
* Category G (exclusive necromutilophiles) eg. [[Robert Napper]], [[Peter Sutcliffe]]
* Category H (sexual [[Human cannibalism|cannibals]] & vampires) eg. [[Albert Fish]], [[Peter Kürten|Peter Kurten]]<ref name=":0" /> 
Dabblers have transitory opportunistic sexual relations with corpses, but this is not their preference. Category F homicidal necrophiles commit postmortem sex acts only while in a [[Fredric Wertham|catathymic]] state. Exclusive mutilophiles derive pleasure purely from mutilating the corpse, while sexual [[Human cannibalism|cannibals]] and vampires are sexually aroused by eating human body parts. Category A, C, and F offenders may also cannibalize or drink the blood of their victims.<ref name=":0" /> 

==Research==

===Humans===
Necrophilia is often assumed to be rare, but no data for its prevalence in the general population exists.<ref>{{cite book | author =  Milner, J. S., Dopke, C. A., & Crouch, J. L.  | date= 2008 | title = Sexual Deviance: Theory, Assessment, and Treatment, 2nd edition | publisher = The Guilford Press | page = 399 | chapter = Paraphilia Not Otherwise Specified: Psychopathology and Theory | editor = Laws, D. Richard}}</ref> Some necrophiles only fantasize about the act, without carrying it out.<ref name="rosman" /> In 1958, Klaf and Brown commented that, although rarely described, necrophiliac [[fantasy (psychology)|fantasies]] may occur more often than is generally supposed.<ref name="klaf"/>

Rosman and Resnick (1989) reviewed 122 cases of necrophilia. The sample was divided into genuine necrophiles, who had a persistent attraction to corpses, and pseudo-necrophiles, who acted out of opportunity, sadism, or transient interest.  Of the total, 92% were male and 8% were female. 57% of the genuine necrophiles had occupational access to corpses, with morgue attendant, hospital orderly, and cemetery employee being the most common jobs. The researchers theorized that either of the following situations could be antecedents to necrophilia:<ref name="rosman" />
#The necrophile develops poor [[self-esteem]], perhaps due in part to a significant loss;
#:(a) They are very fearful of rejection by others and they desire a sexual partner who is incapable of rejecting them; and/or
#:(b) They are fearful of the dead, and transform their fear—by means of [[reaction formation]]—into a desire.
#They develop an exciting fantasy of sex with a corpse, sometimes after exposure to a corpse.

The authors reported that, of their sample of genuine necrophiles:<ref name="rosman" />
*68% were motivated by a desire for an unresisting and unrejecting partner;
*21% by a want for reunion with a lost partner;
*15% by sexual attraction to dead people;
*15% by a desire for comfort or to overcome feelings of isolation; and
*12% by a desire to remedy low self-esteem by expressing power over a corpse.

IQ data was limited, but not abnormally low. About half of the sample had a personality disorder, and 11% of true necrophiles were psychotic. Rosman and Resnick concluded that their data challenged the conventional view of necrophiles as generally psychotic, mentally deficient, or unable to obtain a consenting partner.<ref name="rosman" />

===Other animals===
[[File:Salvator merianae - necrophilia.jpg|thumb|290px|A male [[Argentine black and white tegu|black and white tegu]] mounts a female that has been dead for two days and attempts to mate.<ref name="sazima" />]]
{{see also|Non-reproductive sexual behavior in animals}}

Necrophilia has been observed in mammals, birds, reptiles and frogs.<ref name="demattos">{{cite journal | author = de Mattos Brito, L. B., Joventino, I. R., Ribeiro, S. C., & Cascon, P. | year = 2012 | title = Necrophiliac behavior in the "cururu" toad, ''Rhinella jimi'' Steuvax, 2002, (Anura, Bufonidae) from Northeastern Brazil | journal = North-Western Journal of Zoology | volume = 8 | issue = 2 | page = 365 | url = http://biozoojournals.ro/nwjz/content/v8n2/nwjz.121206.Brito.pdf}}</ref> In 1960, Robert Dickerman described necrophilia in [[ground squirrel]]s, which he termed "Davian behavior" in reference to a [[limerick (poetry)|limerick]] about a necrophiliac miner named Dave. The label is still used for necrophilia in animals.<ref name="costa" /> Certain species of arachnids and insects practice [[sexual cannibalism]], in which the female cannibalizes her male mate prior to, during, or after copulation.

[[Kees Moeliker]] made one observation while he was sitting in his office at the [[Natural History Museum Rotterdam]], when he heard the distinctive thud of a bird hitting the glass facade of the building. Upon inspection, he discovered a drake (male) [[mallard]] lying dead outside the building. Next to the downed bird there was a second drake mallard standing close by. As Moeliker observed the couple, the living drake pecked at the corpse of the dead one for a few minutes  then mounted the corpse and began copulating with it. The act of necrophilia lasted for about 75 minutes, in which time, according to Moeliker, the living drake took two short breaks before resuming with copulating behavior. Moeliker surmised that at the time of the collision with the window the two mallards were engaged in a common pattern in [[duck]] behavior called "attempted [[rape]] flight". "When one died the other one just went for it and didn't get any negative feedback — well, didn't get any feedback," according to Moeliker.<ref name="Mallard Duck">{{cite journal | author=C.W. Moeliker| title=The first case of homosexual necrophilia in the Anas platyrhynchos (Aves:Anatidae)| journal=Deinsea - Annual of the Natural History Museum Rotterdam| year=2001| volume=8| pages=243–247 |url=http://www.chm.bris.ac.uk/sillymolecules/papers/duck.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=7 December 2013}}</ref><ref name="MallardDuck">{{cite news | url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/story/0,9865,1432991,00.html | title = Necrophilia among ducks ruffles research feathers|accessdate = 2007-06-17|publisher=Guardian Unlimited|author=Donald MacLeod | location=London | date=8 March 2005| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131207231131/http://www.theguardian.com/education/2005/mar/08/highereducation.research| archivedate=2013-12-07 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Necrophilia had previously only been reported in heterosexual mallard pairs.<ref name="Mallard Duck" />

In a short paper known as "Sexual Habits of the Adélie Penguin", deemed too shocking for contemporary publication, [[George Murray Levick]] described "little hooligan bands" of penguins mating with dead females in the [[Cape Adare]] [[rookery]], the largest group of [[Adélie penguin]]s, in 1911 and 1912.<ref>{{cite news|last=McKie|first=Robin|title='Sexual depravity' of penguins that Antarctic scientist dared not reveal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jun/09/sex-depravity-penguins-scott-antarctic|accessdate=9 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=9 June 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005160644/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jun/09/sex-depravity-penguins-scott-antarctic|archivedate=2013-10-05|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="russel">{{Cite journal | last1 = Russell | first1 = D. G. D. | last2 = Sladen | first2 = W. J. L. | last3 = Ainley | first3 = D. G. | title = Dr. George Murray Levick (1876–1956): Unpublished notes on the sexual habits of the Adélie penguin | doi = 10.1017/S0032247412000216 | journal = Polar Record | volume = 48 | issue = 4 | pages = 1 | year = 2012 | pmid =  | pmc = }}</ref> This is nowadays ascribed to lack of experience of young penguins; a dead female, with eyes half-closed, closely resembles a compliant female.<ref name="GD2012">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jun/09/sex-depravity-penguins-scott-antarctic |title='Sexual depravity' of penguins that Antarctic scientist dared not reveal |newspaper=Guardian.co.uk |date=9 June 2012 |first=Robin |last=McKie |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104114948/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jun/09/sex-depravity-penguins-scott-antarctic |archivedate=2013-11-04 |deadurl=no}}</ref> A [[gentoo penguin]] was observed attempting to have intercourse with a dead penguin in 1921.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Bagshawe, T. W. | year = 1938 | title = Notes on the Habits of the Gentoo and Ringed or Antarctic Penguins | journal = The Transactions of the Zoological Society of London | volume = 24 | issue = 3 | page = 209 | doi=10.1111/j.1096-3642.1938.tb00391.x}}</ref>

A male [[New Zealand sea lion]] was once observed attempting to copulate with a dead female [[New Zealand fur seal]] in the wild. The sea lion nudged the seal repeatedly, then mounted her and made several pelvic thrusts. Approximately ten minutes later, the sea lion became disturbed by the researcher's presence, dragged the corpse of the seal into the water and swam away while holding it.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Wilson, G. J. | year = 1979 | title = Hooker's sea lions in southern New Zealand | journal = New Zealand Journal of Marine and Freshwater Research | volume = 13 | issue = 3 | pages = 373–375 | url = http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/00288330.1979.9515812 | doi=10.1080/00288330.1979.9515812}}</ref> A male [[sea otter]] was observed holding a female sea otter underwater until she drowned, and then repeatedly copulating with her carcass. Several months later, the same sea otter was again observed copulating with the carcass of a different female.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Harris, H. S., Oates, S. C., Staedler, M. M., Tinker, M. T., Jessup, D. A., Harvey, J. T., & Miller, M. A. | year = 2010 | title = Lesions and behavior associated with forced copulation of juvenile Pacific harbor seals (''Phoca vitulina richardsi'') by southern sea otters (''Enhydra lutris nereis'') | journal = Aquatic Mammals | volume = 36 | issue = 4 | page = 338 | url = http://werc.ucsc.edu/Publications/2010%20Harris%20et%20al.pdf | doi=10.1578/am.36.4.2010.331}}</ref> Copulation with a dead female [[pilot whale]] by a captive male pilot whale has been observed,<ref>{{cite journal | author = Brown, D. H. | year = 1962 | title = Further observations on the pilot whale in captivity | journal = Zoologica | volume = 47 | issue = 1 | pages = 59–64}}</ref> and possible sexual behavior between two male [[humpback whale]]s, one dead, has also been reported.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Pack, A. A., Salden, D. R., Ferrari, M. J., Glockner‐Ferrari, D. A., Herman, L. M., Stubbs, H. A., & Straley, J. M. | year = 1998 | title = Male humpback whale dies in competitive group | journal = Marine Mammal Science | volume = 14 | issue = 4 | pages = 861–873 | doi=10.1111/j.1748-7692.1998.tb00771.x}}</ref>

In 1983, a male [[rock dove]] was observed copulating with the corpse of a dove that had shortly before had its head crushed by a car.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Slavid, Evelyn |author2=Taylor, Julie | year = 1987 | title = Feral Rock Dove displaying to and attempting to copulate with corpse of another | journal = British Birds | volume = 8 | issue = 10 | page = 497 | url = http://www.britishbirds.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/article_files/V80/V80_N10/V80_N10_P492_502_N115.pdf}}</ref><ref name="Guardian 2: Electric Boogaloo">{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/education/2005/mar/14/research.highereducation | title = Randy rock doves join party with the dead | accessdate = 2007-06-17 | work = [[The Guardian]] | location=London | date=14 March 2005}}</ref> In 2001, a researcher laid out [[sand martin]] corpses to attract flocks of other sand martins. In each of six trials, 1-5 individuals from flocks of 50-500 were observed attempting to copulate with the dead sand martins. This occurred one to two months after the breeding season; since copulation outside the breeding season is uncommon among birds, the researcher speculated that the lack of resistance by the corpses stimulated the behavior.<ref name="dale">{{cite journal | author = Dale, S. | year = 2001 | title = Necrophilic behaviour, corpses as nuclei of resting flock formation, and road-kills of Sand Martins ''Riparia riparia'' | journal = Ardea | volume = 89 | issue = 3 | pages = 545–547 | url = http://www.avibirds.com/pdf/O/Oeverzwaluw3.pdf}}</ref> Charles Brown observed at least ten [[cliff swallow]]s attempt to copulate with a road-killed cliff swallow in the space of 15 minutes. He commented, "This isn't the first time I've seen cliff swallows do this; the bright orange rump sticking up seems to be all the stimulus these birds need."<ref>{{cite book | author = Charles Robert Brown | year = 1998 | title = Swallow Summer | publisher = University of Nebraska Press | page = 143}}</ref> Necrophilia has also been reported in the [[European swallow]], [[grey-backed sparrow-lark]], [[Stark's lark]],<ref name="russel" /> and the [[snow goose]].<ref>{{cite journal | author = McKinney, F., & Evarts, S. | year = 1998 | title = Sexual coercion in waterfowl and other birds | journal = Ornithological Monographs | pages = 163–195 | doi = 10.2307/40166723}} The primary source ([https://sora.unm.edu/sites/default/files/journals/condor/v093n03/p0701-p0711.pdf Gauthier & Tardif, 1991]) states that "a paired male attempted to mount a recently shot bird used to attract other geese."</ref> A Norwegian television report showed a male [[hybrid (biology)|hybrid]] between a [[black grouse]] and [[western capercaillie]] kill a male black grouse before attempting to copulate with it.<ref name="dale" />

[[File:Ameiva ameiva - necrophilia.jpg|thumb|290px|A male [[giant ameiva]] mounts a dead female and attempts to pair cloacae.<ref name="costa" />]]

Necrophilia has been documented in various lizard species, including the [[giant ameiva]],<ref name="costa">{{cite journal | author = Costa, H. C., da Silva, E. T., Campos, P. S., da Cunha Oliveira, M. P., Nunes, A. V., & da Silva Santos, P. | year = 2010 | title = The corpse bride: a case of Davian behaviour in the green ameiva (''Ameiva ameiva'') in southeastern Brazil | journal = Herpetology Notes | volume = 3 | pages = 79–83 | url = http://herpetologynotes.seh-herpetology.org/Volume3_PDFs/Costa_et_al_Herpetology_Notes_Volume3_pages079-083.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author = Vitt, L.J. | year = 2003 | chapter = Life versus sex: the ultimate choice | title = Lizards: Windows to the Evolution of Diversity | page = 103 | publisher = University of California Press}}</ref> the [[leopard lizard]],<ref>{{cite journal | author = Fallahpour, K. | year = 2005 | title = ''Gambelia wislizenii''. Necrophilia. | journal = Herpetological Review | volume = 36 | pages = 177–178}} Cited in Sazima (2015).</ref> and ''[[Holbrookia maculata]]''.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Brinker, A.M, Bucklin, S.E. | year = 2006 | title = ''Holbrookia maculata''. Necrophilia. | journal = Herpetological Review | volume = 37 | page = 466}} Cited in Sazima (2015).</ref> There are two reports of necrophilic behavior in the sleepy lizard (''[[Tiliqua rugosa]]''). In one, the partner of a male lizard got caught in fencing wire and died. The male continued to display courtship behavior towards his partner two days after her death. This lizard's necrophilia was believed to stem from its strong [[Monogamous pairing in animals|monogamous]] bond.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Bull, C. Michael | title = Monogamy in lizards | journal = Behavioural Processes | volume = 51 | issue = 1 | page = 12 | url = http://aerg.canberra.edu.au/library/sex_reptile/2000_Bull_monogamy_in_lizards.pdf | doi=10.1016/s0376-6357(00)00115-7}}</ref> In one study of [[Argentine black and white tegu|black and white tegu]] lizards, two different males were observed attempting to court and copulate with a single female corpse on two consecutive days. On the first day, the corpse was freshly dead, but by the second day it was bloating and emitting a strong putrefying odor. The researcher attributed the behavior to [[sex pheromone]]s still acting on the carcass.<ref name="sazima">{{cite journal | author = Sazima, I. | year = 2015 | title = Corpse bride irresistible: a dead female tegu lizard (''Salvator merianae'') courted by males for two days at an urban park in South-eastern Brazil | journal = Herpetology Notes | volume = 8 | pages = 15–18 | url = http://www.biotaxa.org/hn/article/download/9131/11610}}</ref>

Male [[garter snake]]s often copulate with dead females.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Shine, R., O’Connor, D., & Mason, R. T. | year = 2000 | title = Sexual conflict in the snake den | journal = Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology | volume = 48 | issue = 5 | page = 397 | url = http://masonlab.science.oregonstate.edu/files/masonlab/055sexualconflict.pdf | doi=10.1007/s002650000255}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Joy, J. ==Legality==

===Brazil===

Article 212 of the Brazilian Penal Code (federal Decree-Law No 2.848) states as follows:<ref name=bpc>{{Cite web |url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/decreto-lei/Del2848compilado.htm |title=Código Penal (Decreto-Lei nº 2.848) |publisher=Presidency of the Republic |date=December 7, 1940 |accessdate=2016-01-07}}</ref><ref>Free translation from Brazilian Portuguese to English.</ref>
		 
<blockquote>Art. 212 - To abuse a cadaver or its ashes:<br>Penalty: detention, from 1 to 3 years, plus fine.</blockquote>
 
Although sex with a corpse is not explicitly mentioned, a person who has sex with a corpse may be convicted of  a crime under the above Article. The legal asset protected by such Article is not the corpse's objective honor, but the feeling of good memories, respect and veneration that living people keep about the deceased person: these persons are considered passive subjects of the corpse's violation.

===India===
Section 297 of the Indian Penal Code entitled "Trespassing on burial places, etc.", states as follows:<ref name="ipc">{{cite web|url=http://mynation.net/ipc.htm#_Toc496765169 |title=The Indian Penal Code (IPC): Dowry Law Misuse (IPC 448) By Indian Women |publisher=Mynation.net |date= |accessdate=2013-12-07}}</ref>

<blockquote>Whoever, with the intention of wounding the feelings of any person, or of insulting the religion of any person, or with the knowledge that the feelings of any person are likely to be wounded, or that the religion of any person is likely to be insulted thereby,
commits any trespass in any place of worship or on any place of sculpture, or any place set apart from the performance of funeral rites or as a depository for the remains of the dead, or offers any indignity to any human corpse, or causes disturbance to any persons assembled for the performance of funeral ceremonies, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.</blockquote>

Although sex with a corpse is not explicitly mentioned, a person who has sex with a corpse may be convicted under the above section. [[Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code]] could also be invoked.

===New Zealand===
Under Section 150 of the New Zealand [[Crimes Act 1961]], it is an offence for there to be "misconduct in respect to human remains". Subsection (b) elaborates that this applies if someone "improperly or indecently interferes with or offers indignity to any dead human body or human remains, whether buried or not". This statute is therefore applicable to sex with corpses and carries a potential two-year prison sentence, although there is no case law as yet that would apply the aforementioned statute.<ref>Butterworths Crimes Act 1961: Wellington: Butterworths: 2003</ref>

===South Africa===
Section 14 of the [[Criminal Law (Sexual Offences and Related Matters) Amendment Act, 2007]] prohibits the commission of a sexual act with a corpse.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justice.gov.za/legislation/acts/2007-032.pdf |format=PDF |title=Criminal Law (Sexual Offences and Related Matters) Amendment Act 32 of 2007 |at=sec. 14 |date=December 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120523214416/http://www.justice.gov.za/legislation/acts/2007-032.pdf |archivedate=2012-05-23 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Until codified by the act it was a [[common law offence]].

===Sweden===
Section 16, § 10 of the Swedish Penal Code criminalizes necrophilia, but it is not explicitly mentioned. Necrophilia falls under the regulations against abusing a corpse or grave (''brott mot griftefrid''), which carries a maximum sentence of two years in prison. One person has been convicted of necrophilia. He was sentenced to psychiatric care for that and other crimes, including arson. <ref name="HD06">{{Cite news |url=https://www.hd.se/2006-10-06/fakta-nekrofili-och-brott-mot-griftefrid |title=Fakta: Nekrofili och brott mot griftefrid |work=HD |access-date=2017-09-21 |language=sv-SE}}</ref>

===United Kingdom ===
Sexual penetration of a corpse was made illegal under the [[Sexual Offences Act 2003]], carrying a maximum sentence of two years' imprisonment. Prior to 2003, necrophilia was not illegal; however, exposing a naked corpse in public was classed as a [[public nuisance]] (''R v. Clark [1883] 15 Cox 171'').<ref>Aggrawal p.200</ref>

===United States===
There is no federal legislation specifically barring sex with a corpse. Multiple states have their own laws:<ref>{{cite book | author = Aggrawal, Anil | year = 2010 | title = Necrophilia: Forensic and Medico-legal Aspects | publisher = CRC Press | pages = 201–210}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author1=Posner, Richard A. |author2=Silbaugh, Katharine B. | year = 1996 | title = A Guide to America's Sex Laws | publisher = University of Chicago Press | pages = 213–216}}</ref>
